;中国在拉丁美洲（特别是关键基础设施领域）不断上升的影响力和积极的投资策略，美国一名高级军事官员周五表示，这给美国敲响了警钟。

;

;美国南方司令部司令劳拉·理查森将军就拉丁美洲和加勒比地区的安全挑战及其潜力发表了看法在华盛顿智库战略与国际研究中心主办的一次讨论中，讨论了对美国安全的影响。

;

;中国的影响力“绝对是全球性的，就在我们眼皮子底下，离我们的祖国如此之近”，理查森说，他的司令部负责与加勒比海、中美洲和南美洲的应急计划和安全合作。

;

;“中华人民共和国正在做的事情看起来是投资，但我实际上称之为开采......我想说，它处于红色区域。”

;

;理查森说，虽然现在西半球没有中国基地，但北京通过“一带一路”倡议进行的广泛基础设施投资表明，中国有可能建立一个基地。未来，这一事态发展将“显着加剧美国的安全担忧”。

;

;这位将军的言论发表之际，华盛顿对中国在美国附近进行所谓的军事扩张感到不安。

;

;《华尔街日报》6月份援引美国机密情报报道称，中国即将在古巴建立间谍基地。

;

;北京和哈瓦那还讨论了建立联合军事训练设施的问题，进一步深化声明称，华盛顿对中国军队距离美国海岸仅 145 公里（90 英里）感到担忧。

;

;有关中国在古巴间谍基地的报道遭到了拉丁美洲的耸耸肩

;

;白宫随后证实了该基地的存在，并称该基地自 2019 年以来一直在古巴运营。

;

;理查森进一步指出，北京在该地区的技术影响力正在增强，有 5 个国家采用中国的 5G 骨干网，另外还有 24 个国家采用中国的骨干网络将其用于 3G 或 4G 网络。

;

;经济实惠的 5G 升级的吸引力使得这些国家的领导人“通常只有四年任期”很难拒绝中国的提议，她说。

;

;为了对抗北京，理查森主张加强该地区志同道合的民主国家之间的合作，并将这一想法描述为“团队民主的力量”。

;

;5 对中国的贸易举措2023 年在美国的拉丁美洲后院实现了

;

;拉丁美洲领导人“正在研究秒表，而不是日历，我们必须能够有替代方法、替代公司、替代方案他们能够选择……而不是中国竞争对手”，她说。 “这就是我们现在在竞争中被中国人击败的地方。”

;

;这位将军还对中国资助的基础设施在该地区用于军事目的的可能性表示担忧。她指出巴拿马运河沿岸有五家中国国有企业。

;

;具体而言，理查森担心中国公司可能将这些公司用于军事目的，并在南部具有重要战略意义的麦哲伦海峡指出了类似的担忧智利将南美洲大陆与火地群岛分开。

;

;此外，她说，一些加入以中国为中心的“一带一路”倡议的国家正在经历“买家因项目失败而悔恨”。< /p>;

;“该地区乃至全球都有项目进展不顺利的例子，”理查森说。 “它们存在设计缺陷、成本超支。存在巨大的延误。”

;

;但她认为，需要基础设施帮助的国家向北京求助是可以理解的，她说：“当有人向你扔一根绳子时，你不一定要看是谁给的。你是绳子。你只要抓住它。”

;

;因此，理查森敦促美国及其盟友提供替代投资和商业模式，帮助拉美国家抵制中国的影响力。

;

;否则，她警告说， “如果我们不参与竞争，他们就会选择”中国。

;

;习近平告诉拉丁美洲和加勒比地区，中国将与“新时代”建立联系

;

;中国人周五，驻华盛顿大使馆捍卫了“一带一路”倡议。

;

;使馆发言人刘鹏宇表示，其项目的特点是全面对话、相互协作、共享优势，“这体现在它创造了 42 万个就业岗位和”。

;

;“‘一带一路’受到世界各国普遍欢迎，最重要的是因为它是共商、共建、共享的倡议。”刘补充道。

;

;“中国从不把自己的意志强加于其他国家，也不将任何自私的地缘政治议程纳入“一带一路”之中。”

;7月1日是中泰建交48周年。如今，中国是泰国最大的贸易伙伴，去年贸易额达 1,350 亿美元，约占泰国贸易总额的 18%。

;

;泰国对中国的出口额也猛增，从 1995 年的 18.2 亿美元增至 37.7 美元到 2021 年，中国的中产阶级将增长 10 亿美元，这证明了中国新兴的中产阶级以及泰国作为制造业和农业强国的竞争力不断增强。

;

;凭借文化和人际关系的联系，中国家庭明显偏爱在泰国度假和合资企业的成功从医疗保健到尖端初创企业和创新，两国长期以来一直享有资本、人才和知识汇集的协同效应。

;

;“一带一路”倡议在推进区域基础设施建设方面取得了巨大成功泰国是一个有效的东南亚中心地带，通过先进的火车和物流网络将中国与老挝、缅甸、柬埔寨和马来西亚连接起来。

;

;今年早些时候，为泰党领导人 Chonlanan Srikaew 在接待中国代表团时承诺“推动更多贸易协定，促进投资、相互进出口、旅游业以及技术交流”。

;

;然而，为了切实深化、拓宽中泰关系并经受住未来几十年的考验，北京曼谷必须解决房间里的大象：初期的地缘政治紧张局势主要源于中美竞争。

;

;首先，泰国寻求深化与中国的军事协调，同时与泰国保持深厚的军事和防务关系。美国作为主要的非北约盟友。这种做法与泰国的“竹子外交”相一致，即在大国之间谨慎平衡并坚定捍卫国家利益。

;

;然而，随着华盛顿越来越多地向东南亚国家施加压力，要求它们在问题上选边站队。它被认为是为了加强其地区影响力，以应对来自中国的潜在挑战，泰国可能被迫做出选择。

;

;最近和正在进行的一系列联合军事演习反映了北京和曼谷压制中立的共同意图。地区冲突和紧张局势，但它们是在美国重新有兴趣讨好东南亚的背景下发生的。

;

;为了继续中泰军事合作，必须明确划分泰国军队的职权范围和界限需要与美国和中国同行建立关系。更具建设性的是，即将上任的泰国内阁应利用该国与北京和缅甸军队的历史关系，寻求中国与东盟斡旋的和平协议，以恢复缅甸的一点民主。

;

;其次，在全球金融和供应链日益巴尔干化的背景下，泰国应将自己定位为投资的避风港。乌克兰战争引发了跨国公司和资产的一系列重组，其中许多公司从中国转移到东南亚，以寻求更大的政策确定性。

;

;东北亚的中小企业感到担忧由于台湾海峡军事紧张局势的潜在影响，一直将泰国视为成本更低、区域联系更紧密的生产基地。这种撤资激励措施也适用于在国内外寻求增长沃土的中国企业。

;

;泰国对中国国有企业并不陌生，例如与正大集团合作的上汽集团集团将利用泰国作为产品国际化的中心。

;

;泰国东部经济走廊也为海外公司的多元化努力提供了绝佳的机会。同样，面对可能扰乱关键矿产和其他原材料供应的潜在突发事件，泰国制造商必须投资于提高抵御能力和自给自足能力。

;

;泰国的主要政策制定者可以利用该国的资源稀土资源丰富。反过来，在全球地缘政治金融急剧武器化的情况下，北京方面应确保其在泰国的合资企业保持不受制裁和稳健。

;

;最后，任何健康的双边关系的核心都是真诚和扎根的民间交流。 ——人员交流。泰国是中国在疫情过后首批恢复团体旅游的国家之一，副总理兼公共卫生部长阿努廷·查维拉库 (Anutin Charnvirakul) 一月份在素万那普机场迎接中国游客。

;

;虽然泰国企业在很大程度上过去几十年来，虽然中国的购买力和中国市场的天文数字增长使这些国家受益匪浅，但一些人认为，这种红利并没有惠及中下阶层和工薪阶层。

;

;中国的“零美元”游客由于旅游团的消费集中，且大部分返还给中国旅行社，当地对此反应冷淡。乘数效应显然没有发挥作用。

;

;泰国民众与中国游客之间的紧张关系很可能因多种因素而出现，包括经济根源的怨恨，以及刻板印象、宗教分歧或日益政治化的媒体空间中国崛起的观点常常受到既得利益的影响。

;

;在泰国的中国游客因踩珊瑚、摸海星而面临牢狱之灾

;

;泰国政府必须努力确保其媒体不受媒体报道外国干涉以及对与美国和中国关系的报道仍然是平衡、坦诚和以事实为导向的。另一方面，北京必须谨慎、批判性地思考中国如何才能获得更多信任，并赢得泰国人心。

;

;香港当然可以发挥作用。随着行政长官李家超去年首次出访泰国，这座城市的特殊联系显然将变得越来越重要，成为中国与泰国关系的另一个渠道。

;

;;2023.08.04 22:58;

;香港低收入住户在25年里增加了16万户根据政府统计数据，到 2021 年，最贫困家庭的月收入仅为 4,700 港元（602 美元），低于 1996 年。

;

;在这些家庭中，近四分之三的成员是were not part of the labour force, according to a data analysis report released by the Legislative Council on Friday.

;

;The Society for Community Organisation (SoCO) attributed the high proportion of economically inactive households to the Covid-19 pandemic and warned that people unfit to work might be under-represented, urging authorities to enhance day care services and employers to allow more job flexibility.

;

;The Legco report said the number of low-income households, which make up the lowest 20 per cent of income, increased by 44 per cent from 371,000 in 1996 to 534,300 in 2021.

;

;The data showed that the median monthly income among low-income households dropped from HK$5,400 in 1996 to HK$4,700 in 2021, despite a slight increase to HK$5,700 in 2016.

;

;Over the 25-year period, the proportion of economically inactive households among low-income families increased from 34 per cent to 74 per cent, representing close to 400,000 families.

;

;Among these families, 40 per cent, or nearly 160,000, were working-age households, meaning at least one member was under the age of 65. This marks a three-fold increase from the figure in 1996, when the number of working-age and economically inactive households was about 50,000.

;

;Nearly 1 in 4 young Hongkongers from low-income families 'lying flat': survey

;< p>;According to the report, the 160,000 households included more than 200,000 people, and 40 per cent, or 81,300, were homemakers and early retirees with no care responsibilities.

;

;“It might be worth gaining a better understanding of the reasons why they were unable to, or had actively chosen not to participate in the labour market and [help] them overcome the relevant obstacles,” the report said.

;

;“It would not only raise the prospect of improving the income situation of these low-income households, but might even alleviate to a certain extent the impact of a tight labour force on the local economy.”

;

;The report also noted a heavy reliance on social welfare among low-income households, with cash benefits accounting for more than 80 per cent of their household income in 2021, up from only 27 per cent in 1996.

;

;Hong Kong 'to offer 3,000 children after-school care ' under coming pilot scheme

;

;Public expenditure on the cash benefits saw a fourfold increase to HK$70.6 billion in 2021.

;

;Sze Lai-shan, deputy director of SoCO, warned that people unable to work were likely to be under-represented in government statistics, stressing that most poor families were working hard to make ends meet.

;

;“Some people have physical conditions that prevent them from working long hours, but they have not managed to get a medical certificate for the issue,” she said, adding that homemaking duties prevented many women from participating in the labour market, especially those with big families.

;

;'I hope my children will have a good life': what can Hong Kong do to break poverty cycle?

;

;“Those people struggle to find a job because the positions they are fit for, mostly labour-intensive ones, have long working hours and inflexible shifts , but they need to take care of their families at the same time,” she said.

;

;Many members of low-income households had lost their jobs during the Covid-19 pandemic and had to rely on welfare, and while many managed to eventually find employment, their pay was lower, she added.

;

;Sze called on the government to bolster day care services to help low-income families, adding flexible arrangements were needed to cater to parents ' long working hours.

;

;At the same time, employers should allow more flexible scheduling to provide more options for low-income workers, she added.

; Fri, 04 Aug 2023 23:20:02 +0800 China’s digital yuan ‘at forefront globally’, former central bank governor Yi Gang sayshttps://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3230028/chinas-digital-yuan-forefront-globally-former-central-bank-governor-yi-gang-says?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.04 23:00;
;;

;China's former central bank governor used the final two lectures of his five-year tenure to highlight the digital yuan, hailing it as being “at the forefront globally”.

;

;Yi Gang, 65, was formally replaced by 60-year-old Pan Gongsheng as the head of the People's Bank of China (PBOC) at the end of last month.

;

;“The digital yuan focuses on retail payments, which enables the most significant improvements in efficiency, payment system redundancy and advancing inclusive finance,” Yi said at Tsinghua University in Beijing on July 5, according to a transcript of the closed-door lecture released on Thursday.

;

;China's digital currency, known as the e-CNY, could facilitate a wide range of domestic retail payments, including by foreign visitors, while it also has overseas use, added Yi.

;

;China names new central bank governor as twice-a-decade finance conference nears

;

;The digital yuan, along with green finance initiatives, highlight Yi's legacy as central bank governor, in addition to traditional tasks of helping the coronavirus-hit economy, preventing financial risks and controlling inflation.

;

;Yi is now the president of the Chinese Society for Finance and Banking, while he is also a deputy director under a government advisory body, the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

;

;With Pan now at the helm, the central bank pledged during its midyear work conference this week that it will continue pushing research and trials of the digital yuan, while also enhancing its financial infrastructure and services.

;

;China was the one of the first major economies to study a central bank digital currency, with a research institute chartered under the PBOC in 2016 preceding moves by the European Central Bank and the US Federal Reserve.

;

;The PBOC has designed a two-tier centralised digital yuan, which is primarily used for retail payments, with pilot schemes conducted in 17 provinces.

;

;It has managed anonymity in payments to ease market concerns over privacy, and it wants to dilute its store of value function “because it will generate other problems”, Yi added.

;

;The PBOC will also prioritise monetary sovereignty in cross-border use of the digital yuan, aiming to increase efficiency and lower costs.

;

;As of March, 891.86 billion yuan (US$124 billion) has been spent across 750 million digital yuan transactions.

;

;Around 100 million e-wallets have also been opened through the digital yuan app, with a total balance of 8.67 billion yuan.

;

;“The promotion of the e-CNY should be market oriented, not by administrative orders,” Yi told a lecture hosted by the Monetary Authority of Singapore on July 19.

;

;“The e-CNY will coexist with physical cash for a long time. As long as there's demand for physical cash, the PBOC shall not stop the supply.”

;

;China's digital yuan has been used in a variety of payment scenarios, from shopping, utility bill payment, payroll and cross-border transactions.

;

;In June, a new e-CNY exchange machine was set up in the holiday resort of Sanya on the island province of Hainan.

;

;It facilitates the exchange of 20 different currencies for digital yuan, offering foreign visitors access to a local mobile payments ecosystem.

;Politicians from three major Hong Kong parties have petitioned the Department of Justice to appeal a court's dismissal of a government bid to ban the promotion of a protest anthem that became popular during the 2019 social unrest.

;

;A source close to the government told the Post the administration would probably appeal against the High Court's rejection of its application for an injunction to ban the promotion of “Glory to Hong Kong”.

;

;Lawmakers from the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong (DAB), the Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions (FTU) and the Liberal Party posted on Facebook within hours of each other on Friday asking government lawyers to consider an appeal against the ruling.

;

;Lawmakers from the three political groups said there was a need for the government to outlaw the protest song once and for all and denied that they had coordinated their calls for an appeal to be lodged.

;

;Liberal Party chairman Peter Shiu Ka-fai told the Post the government was forced to resort to legal action because search engines and streaming platforms had refused to remove the song.

;

;“The Hong Kong government has already expressed the inappropriateness of this song. [ …] If self-discipline [among online platforms] resolves the issue, we don't need to resort to an injunction,” Shiu said.

;

;The court ruling questioned the effectiveness of a ban and highlighted that the publication and distribution of the song was punishable under laws already on the books.

;

;The judgment added a ban might not compel internet search giant Google and other technology firms to remove the song from their services.

;

;But Mr Justice Anthony Chan Kin-keung said he would have ruled in favour of the government had it not been for these problems and the injunction's lack of usefulness,

;

;Chan maintained the potential chilling effects of a ban would not outweigh the fundamental need to safeguard national security.

;

;Hong Kong court dismisses government bid to ban protest song

;

;But Shiu said he was convinced the government would not have applied for an injunction if existing legislation, such as the national security law, could have been used instead.

;

;Holden Chow Ho-ding, the DAB vice-chairman and a lawyer, also rejected Chan's argument about the potential chilling effects of the injunction in a Facebook post on Friday.

;

;He told the Post later he found the legal reasons behind the ruling faulty.

;

;“It is ubiquitously known that this song is used to promote Hong Kong's independence. This is completely a national security problem, why would freedom of speech be dragged into this?” he said on Facebook.

;

;Chow warned that the court ruling could also set a legal precedent for future cases if the government decided not to appeal.

;

;Kingsley Wong Kwok, the FTU chairman, said it would be a mistake to drop the battle for an injunction and risk national security.

;

;“I think the government, courts and the judiciary all need to deal with this problem. We should not sacrifice national security over technical issues, for the nation's security is the bottom line,” Wong said.

;

;A justice department spokesman on Friday said officials would study the judgment and consider the next move.

;

;AmCham hails court rejection of bid to ban 'Glory to Hong Kong' protest song

;

;Secretary for Justice Paul Lam Ting-kwok lodged the application last month in a bid to bar promotion of “Glory to Hong Kong” through “broadcasting, performing, printing, publishing, selling, offering for sale, distributing, disseminating, displaying or reproducing in any way”.

;

;The authorities maintain the song contained lyrics that threatened national security, such as an appeal to “Liberate Hong Kong” in a “revolution of our times”.

;

;The expression was found to be capable of carrying a secessionist meaning in the city's first national security trial.

;

;“Glory to Hong Kong” was played by mistake instead of the Chinese national anthem “March of the Volunteers” at several overseas sports events.

;

;The anti-government song gained popularity among Hong Kong's mostly young protesters soon after its creation during the unrest triggered by a now-withdrawn extradition bill.

; Fri, 04 Aug 2023 23:20:02 +0800 Japan boy band producer Johnny Kitagawa’s abuse victims deserve apologies and compensation, says UNhttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/3230061/japan-boy-band-producer-johnny-kitagawas-abuse-victims-deserve-apologies-and-compensation-says-un?utm_source=rss_feed

;The men who came forward to allege they were sexually abused as teenagers by Japanese boy band producer Johnny Kitagawa now have a powerful listener: the United Nations.

;

;Damilola Olawuyi, chair of the UN Working Group on Business and Human Rights, told reporters on Friday that the number of victims may total several hundred, and he accused Japan's mainstream media of standing silent about the alleged abuse for decades.

;

;Olawuyi raised serious questions about the sincerity of the response from the talent agency Kitagawa founded, Johnny & Associates. He urged other entertainment industry players to carry out a “transparent and legitimate investigation with a clear timeline”.

;

;Junya Hiramoto, one of seven men who talked with Olawuyi's team, was moved to tears by the UN official's remarks.

;

;“I felt our message had been clearly relayed,” he said. “They gave me such courage.”

;

;Pichamon Yeophantong, a member of the UN group who appeared with Olawuyi at the Japan National Press Club in Tokyo, urged the Japanese government to do more.

;

;“This case highlights the need for the government, as the primary duty-bearer, to ensure transparent investigations of perpetrators and that victims obtain effective remedies, be they in the form of an apology or financial compensation,” she said.

;

;Olawuyi and other experts have been in Japan since July 24. They met with government officials, human rights advocates, trade unions and companies, to learn about how businesses may be violating human rights and harming the environment.

;

;A full report is set to be presented to the UN Human Rights Council in June, which will include recommendations for change.

;

;Foremost on the Working Group's agenda was the men who allege they were sexually abused as children by Kitagawa, who was a powerful figure in Japan's entertainment industry before he died in 2019, in his 80s. The head of Johnny & Associates apologised in May.

;

;Critics say what happened at Johnny's, as the company is known in Japan, is shameful and indicative of how the nation, apparently a democratic and economic powerhouse, lags behind in its protection of human rights.

;

;The men who have come forward say Kitagawa abused them in his Tokyo luxury mansion, as well as in other places like his car and overseas hotels, while they performed as dancers and singers.

;

;Kitagawa was never charged. He was revered over the years, although allegations about abuse popped up now and then, only to be eventually shrugged off.

;

;“What is the worst case of sexual abuse in the history of humankind is seeing the light of day,” said Shimon Ishimaru, one of the seven accusers to go public. “这个问题是真实存在的。 It really happened.”

;

;Johnny's, which is still thriving, set up an investigative panel, but what it plans to achieve has been unclear. Ishimaru and others said they were sceptical because they had not received the mental healthcare the company promised.

;

;In response to a request for comment, Johnny & Associates said all matters are being dealt with as part of the investigation.

;

;After a BBC documentary about Kitagawa aired this year, musician Kauan Okamoto spoke in April at the Foreign Correspondents' Club in Tokyo, the first person in decades to make such allegations under his real name.

;

;The Associated Press does not usually identify people who say they were sexually assaulted, but Kitagawa's recent accusers decided to be named publicly in news accounts.

;

;Kitagawa filed a libel suit against weekly magazine Shukan Bunshun after it published a series of 1999 articles based on anonymous interviews with former performers who said he forced them to have sex.

;

;A few years later, Japan's Supreme Court upheld an appeals court finding in favour of Shukan Bunshun, saying the accusers' testimonies were reliable, and what they said had really happened.

;

;Sex abuse report casts shadow over Pope Francis' Portugal visit

;

;What Japan does now may end up being a litmus test for a country where legal revision that officially banned violence against children kicked in only three years ago and reports of child abuse and neglect of children are rampant. Japan raised the age of sexual consent from 13 to 16 only this year.

;

;Akimasa Nihongi, one of the seven men who spoke with the UN officials, said people like him had suffered enough. He praised the UN's actions as a big step forward.

;

;“A collective voice can ring loud and clear,” Nihongi said.

;

;“The UN Working Group sincerely listened to what we said. And they have now spoken.”

;;

;The first phase of China's highest altitude wind farm has been plugged into Tibet's power grid, with plans to expand the system.

;

;The official Science and Technology Daily reported on Friday that the wind farm in Cuomei county, in the autonomous region's southeast, comprised a series of turbines installed at at least 5,000 metres (16,400 feet) above sea level.

;

;The project has been developed by the China Three Gorges Corporation and, once completed, is expected to feed up to 200 million KWh into the grid each year, or enough power to meet the demand of almost 140,000 households, according to state broadcaster CCTV.

;

;Wang Liang, head of the Shannan branch of the corporation's Tibet Energy Investment, told CCTV that the turbines were optimised for the high-altitude environment, with each turbine blade longer than similar units built at lower altitudes.

;

;Wang said the extra blade length would increase the area swept by the turbines by nearly 30 per cent, improving the system's wind efficiency in the low atmospheric pressure.

;

;Typically ultra-high wind farms built between 3,500 and 5,500 metres are considered ultra-high altitude.

;

;Atmospheric pressure decreases with altitude, reducing the energy generated by wind turbines.

;

;But Wang told CCTV that the project would prove the viability of ultra-high altitude wind projects, disproving the suggestion that winds in the area would be too weak to have any developmental value.

;

;He said that 30 per cent of the Tibetan region had winds of at least 25km/h but these areas were mainly at altitudes of above 4,800 metres.

;

;According to the US Energy Information Administration, speeds above 20.9km/h are viable for utility-scale turbines.

;

;Wang said the project would lay the foundation for future farms and fill an industry gap.

;

;Liu Chunshan head of turbine technology at the farm, said the turbines had also been designed to withstand the harsh environment of the Tibetan Plateau.

;

;The paint used on the surface of the turbines' blades was highly elastic, making it resistant to the extreme weather on the plateau, Liu said.

;

;According to Wang, the turbines are also resistant to low temperatures and ice, and fitted with lightning protection technology.

;

;In addition, the turbines were designed to limit their impact on the area's fragile environment.

;

;The turbines were set further apart to have less impact on animal grazing and topsoil removed to install the turbines was set aside to be reused after the project is completed.

;

;Based on the success of the first phase, Wang said the company would continue investing in the technology and bring more turbines online at the farm in the future.

;

;He said that due to the weather and complex terrain, it took about two months to transport the parts for the turbines to the farm site. Detailed road surveys were conducted in order to complete the process, Wang said.

;

;Wind power installation has continued to rise in the first half of this year, with 10.4 gigawatts of newly installed capacity, according to the National Energy Administration. The total installed wind capacity in China reached 389GW as of the end of June.
